descriptionSet.description: Two women in a garment shop in an urban space can be seen in this image. A sign in the shop reads "The India Fine Cloth House". Their saris are embossed with gilt and glitter. One woman holds up one cloth to examine it while another looks on, holding a thick book in her left hand. A phone stands on the display table. The backdrop of the shop shows a large street with pavement and fenced park, a clock tower and a railway station as well as several high building (c. 8 storeys). Two cars, several people walking and a horse carriage can be seen. A full moon can be seen through the clouds.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: Motilal, A. Bhuralal
text-en: The India Fine Cloth House
text-en: A. Bhuralal Motilal Nathdwara [..V]

description-en: Two women in a garment shop in an urban space can be seen in this image. A sign in the shop reads "The India Fine Cloth House". Their saris are embossed with gilt and glitter. One woman holds up one cloth to examine it while another looks on, holding a thick book in her left hand. A phone stands on the display table. The backdrop of the shop shows a large street with pavement and fenced park, a clock tower and a railway station as well as several high building (c. 8 storeys). Two cars, several people walking and a horse carriage can be seen. A full moon can be seen through the clouds. (gs/cb)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image returns us emphatically to the fundamental connections among consumption, identity, and the acts of and about the everyday. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The fact that the sign is in English shows that the audience addressed is assumed to read English, thus belong to the educated classes. The 'atmosphere' of the picture is a surreal mixture of sacred-picturesque (full moon, night) and use of embossment that can usually be found on pictures with deities. This might be explained through the reference to Nathdwara where a whole tradition of god paintings but also 'secular' images has developed over time.() (cb)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)
